A vs B",clear to understand (visualization)

Participants rated different factors on a five-point Likert scale in two aspects: clarity (clear to understand) and readability (easy to read). In addition, they were asked to list the three most effective design choices in order.

After performing the tasks, they were asked to rate the two choices in terms of clarity and readability. To avoid bias, the statements were provided in two opposite manner: the first stated in the form that “A is better than B” and the second stated in the form that “B is better than A”.",clear to understand

or ""Non applicable""",(cf ICE-T),"The ICE-T evaluation form focuses on the value in and the interactivity of visualizations.
Insight is the ability to impel and identify insights or insightful questions about the data.
Confidence is the ability to produce confidence and trustworthiness in the data.
Essence is the capability to communicate concisely an overall essence of the data.
Time is the capability to reduce the necessary total time to respond to a large variety of queries about data.",,

column11: innovative - conventional,"Attitude study: Adapting the semantic differential technique used by Dent [32] and Nusrat et al. [10], we asked participants to rate the aesthetics and effectiveness of the three interactive features evaluated in the experiment. We selected pairs of opposite words (e.g., “conventional” versus “innovative,” “hindering” versus “helpful”). For every pair of words, we asked participants to rate each interactive feature on a 5-point Likert scale. Following the example of [10], participants did not have to give separate responses for each task type. Hence, the participants responded three times to each word pair, once for each interactive feature.",,

column1: Each participant rated each visualization once based on a single specification.
4 conditions: baseline (vis without specification) + 3 types of specifications
!! in this study ""readability"" and ""memorability"" are names of conditions and tested through accuracy of answers !!

Accuracy: readability & memorability - The no-visualization baseline condition allows us to determine the question’s baseline difficulty based on guessing and prior knowledge. Then, we evaluated readability accuracy for answering the assessment while viewing the visualization. Finally, we evaluated the memorability accuracy on how effective the visualizations were for information that was to be remembered.",,

column7: ,"Usability, Interpretability, Trust: 1 to 5 (1 = Strongly disagree, 5 = Strongly agree)

column1: Workload: 1 to 5 (1 = very low, 5 = very high)
Accountability: 1 to 5 (1 = System’s capability, 5 = My input to the system)
,mentally demanding (task); hard (work); ,Each participant was asked to answer a set of 13 survey questions to quantitatively measure usability, interpretability, workload, accountability and trust.
- To capture cognitive workload, we selected two applicable questions from the NASA-LTX task load index [23]
- For capturing usability, we picked 3 questions from the System Usability Scale (SUS) [7]
- To capture accountability, we asked two questions based on previous studies [9, 19].
- To capture interpretability, we consulted Madsen Gregor scale [30] and adopted 3 questions for our application.
- For measuring trust, we referred to McKnight’s framework on Trust [31, 32] and other studies [15, 19] to come up with 3 questions for our specific case.",,

confident, 2 = Not confident, 3 = Neutral, 4 = Confident, 5 = Highly confident)
